A European Union plan to tax Google, Facebook and other internet firms risks failure after a handful of member states announced their opposition.

EU countries are studying proposals to levy a 3% tax on big internet companies that make money from user data or digital advertising, in a bid to level the playing field with bricks-and-mortar companies that pay more tax.

But the idea, which must be agreed unanimously by all 28 member states, is running into serious opposition, as Ireland, Sweden and Denmark made their criticism public on Tuesday.

Germany had initially supported the idea in a joint agreement with France, but is now seeking to water down and delay the proposals, moves that are causing deep frustration in Paris.

A dozen countries are moving ahead with their own national digital taxes, with Spain and the UK among the recent converts.

The chancellor, Philip Hammond, announced last week that the UK was prepared to go it alone, with a “narrowly-targeted” digital services tax that is expected to come into force in April 2020 and raise £400m for the exchequer.

Opponents to the digital tax fear the wrath of Donald Trump’s White House, which regards the EU’s efforts to ensure “fair taxation” of internet giants as an attack on American companies, a charge the EU rejects.

Denmark’s finance minister, Kristian Jensen, said that given the way that the tax “has been framed as aiming at US companies, of course there will be a reaction from the United States.”

Ireland, which hosts big tech firms including Apple, Facebook and Google, is also opposed. “What kind of reaction would this bring if this was a model that was imposed on us?” Irish finance minister Paschal Donohoe asked his counterparts during the live-streamed debate.

The French finance minister, Bruno Le Maire, argues that an EU digital tax could spur efforts for an international agreement, led by the the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development thinktank.

Paris fears that failure to agree such a high-profile proposal before May’s European elections will be a gift to anti-EU populists, such as Marine Le Pen, the leader of the National Rally, formerly the Front National, who claim the EU is in hock to big business.

But Le Maire offered a big concession, when he announced on Tuesday that France would support delaying the introduction of an EU tax to allow the OECD to make a comprehensive proposal.

Behind the scenes, Paris is deeply disappointed that Berlin has gone cool on the idea after the two countries agreed the initiative more than 18 months ago and reaffirmed it in June in the Meseburg declaration, a Franco-German vision of the EU’s future. It stated the two would aim for “an EU agreement on a fair digital taxation by the end of 2018”.

The French government is unconvinced that US reaction is any reason to delay, arguing that Germany has no excuse if even the UK, traditionally seen as Washington’s closest ally in Europe, can propose a digital tax.

Le Maire still hopes for an agreement in December, but interventions from other member states suggests that is a tall order.

Sweden’s economy minister, Magdalena Andersson, said her country could not support the proposal. “I see no government in Sweden that would have any other opinion on this issue.”

Hartwig Löger, Austria’s finance minister, who chaired the meeting, put a brave face on the divisions, arguing more clarity was needed on whether countries had technical or political objections. “There is the motivation to find a harmonised solution for Europe,” he said after the meeting. “Even now we have 11 countries – soon it will be 12 with Spain – which have national individual solutions on digital taxation.”

The tills on the high street did not ring as frequently last Christmas, as consumers opted to buy their presents earlier, on Black Friday, the annual US-inspired event where shops slash prices to boost sales.

This year it will take place on 23 November and will be followed three days later by Cyber Monday, another import from across the Atlantic aimed at people spending online. So popular have these days become that they encouraged shoppers to increase their spending last year despite a protracted squeeze on household income.

It is likely that once again all the big retailers will take part this year in the weekend of discounts, but are the bargains as good as they would like us to believe? And what do consumers need to beware of when buying on the day that has become the start of Christmas shopping?

Do I need this?

Martin Lewis of MoneySavingExpert has a simple rule when it comes to shopping, which is worth bearing in mind when the Black Friday offers start appearing far in advance of the day itself. Ask yourself whether you need the item you are considering buying and whether you can afford it. Then check to see what the prices are elsewhere.

If you do have some money to spare, ask yourself if you will use it and whether the item is worth buying. And again, make sure that you check the prices elsewhere. There is no point in buying something that has an enormously reduced price but will only gather dust on the shelf once it is delivered.

How much is the discount?

Frequently, a deal is not a deal at all. Last year, consumer group Which? found that many items discounted over the Black Friday weekend could have been bought cheaper or at the same price at other times of the year. More than half of a selection of items surveyed were cheaper before the event and a similar number cost less afterwards.

With that in mind, it is best to research the item you want before you buy. Televisions are likely to be one of the most popular items discounted over the weekend, so if you are aiming to buy one, know what you are looking for in advance instead of wasting time on the day checking whether the one on offer is suitable.

One useful tool for checking the price history of a product is the CamelCamelCamel website, which allows you to check a product’s price history on Amazon. This way, you can see whether the item has ever sold for less than the Black Friday sale price. There are also numerous price-comparison sites that collate the cost of products across the web, such as Google Shopping, PriceSpy, iDealo and PriceRunner.

Am I covered as usual?

As always, just because you are buying in a sale does not mean your rights evaporate. The rules are set out in the Consumer Rights Act: in the event that you buy an item that turns out to be faulty, you should first go to the retailer, recommends Which?. In the first 30 days, you can reject something that is faulty and get your money back. After 30 days, retailers can replace or repair the faulty item instead of giving a refund. Returning goods that are not faulty for a refund or an exchange is possible if a retailer has a returns policy, which is usually within 28 days of purchase.

Under the Consumer Contracts Regulations, you can cancel an online order up to 14 days from the time the goods are delivered to you. It is also up to the retailer to deliver the goods to you and to rectify the situation if there is a problem. The Consumer Rights Act also extends to digital media such as games, ebooks, films and music. If the content is faulty, you can claim a replacement.

Beware of scams

In the frenzy of activity and deal announcements during the sale weekend, it is easy to lose track of where the offers are coming from. Beware of deals that pop up on social media or if there are unsolicited calls on and around the sale days. Last year, Action Fraud warned people to avoid clicking on links from text and WhatsApp messages, over concerns that they may have been hijacked by fraudsters sending texts at the same time as retailers.

Many shops send texts instead of emails to promote their offers under the belief that people are more likely to open links from a text message than they are via email. Action Fraud said people were mostly defrauded by sales of mobiles phones and footwear. Be wary of “too good to be true” prices, carefully check terms and conditions, and read buyer reviews for sites you have not used before that offer cheap prices.

Smart buying tips

Savings made on Black Friday and Cyber Monday can be boosted if you shop smart. Cashback systems and websites can give back points and money on purchases. Using a credit card can offer you more protection if something goes awry.

Under section 75 of the Consumer Credit Act, purchases of more than £100 and up to £30,000 are protected. This covers undelivered and faulty goods, as well as services such as flights. You only need to put the deposit on your card, not the whole cost, and you can pay it off straightaway, so you do not need to get into debt to get the protection.

Putting your purchase details into a retailer’s site in advance means sales can be made quicker, while some retailers will match prices that are being offered by competitors on Black Friday.

Five British companies have failed to appoint a single woman to their boards more than two years after the government ordered the UK’s 350 biggest firms to ensure that women hold at least a third of boardroom positions by 2020.

A further 75 companies were on Tuesday highlighted by the Hampton-Alexander review of UK boardroom diversity for appointing only one woman to their boards in a “tokenistic gesture”.

Sir Philip Hampton, chair of the government-commissioned review, called on consumers to boycott the firms that are “so clearly out of touch”. Hampton, a City grandee and chairman of the pharmaceuticals company GlaxoSmithKline, told the Guardian that politicians, the media and consumers need to put “human pressure” on firms that are damaging the reputation of corporate Britain.

Related: Male bosses' 'pitiful excuses' for lack of women in boardroom criticised

The five FTSE 350-listed companies with all-male boards are Millennium & Copthorne, which operates 120 hotels across the world; Daejan Holdings, which owns a string of office properties including Africa House in London’s Holborn; Amigo Holdings, which provides 49% APR loans; and the investment trusts Herald Investment and JP Morgan Japanese Investment. Amigo appointed a woman to its board last Thursday but is not included in the Hampton-Alexander figures because the decision missed the deadline.

“They are so clearly out of touch,” Hampton said of the five companies. “And it would be good to see pressure from the media, politicians, ourselves [other business leaders] and consumers.”

Hampton said that while it would be hard for consumers to apply pressure on investment trusts, they could avoid staying at Millennium & Copthorne hotels. The FTSE 250 company, which is majority-owned by the Singaporean billionaire Kwek Leng Beng, owns hotels and resorts in 79 countries and is the official partner hotel of Chelsea Football Club. A spokesperson for Millennium declined to comment.

The reasons chairmen and chief executives have cited for failing to appoint more women included: “I don’t think women fit comfortably into the board environment”; “Most women don’t want the hassle or pressure of sitting on a board”; and “All the ‘good’ women have already been snapped up”.

Hampton said that while it was a deep concern that five FTSE 350 companies still had all-male boards, it was a considerable improvement on 152 all-male boards in 2011. Also, FTSE 100 companies are on track to meet the target of having 30% of board positions occupied by women by 2020. In 2011, only 12.5% of FTSE 100 boardroom positions were held by women.

Denise Wilson, the chief executive of the Hampton-Alexander review, said that as well as the firms that still had all-male boards she wanted to highlight 75 companies that have only one woman on their boards. “Some of them have been in that tokenistic place for some time and we are shining a light on them,” Wilson said. Included among the 75 with only one woman on the board is Melrose, the FTSE 100 turnaround specialist that took over the historic engineering company GKN.

Hampton also highlighted the London Stock Exchange Group, which operates the UK and Italian stock exchanges, for having only two women on its board. “You would expect a business like that to be setting a better example,” he said.

Even at companies where there were several women on the board, Hampton said women were more often in non-executive rather than executive roles and were very rarely the chief executive or chair.

There are only six female CEOs in the FTSE 100, an increase of one since 2011. Among the wider FTSE 350 there are only 12 female CEOs, which is a decrease from 15 last year and 18 the year before. There are only 22 female chairs in the FTSE 350.

Rachel Reeves, the chair of the business, energy and industrial strategy committee, said: “The infamous five companies who still have all-male boards need to drag themselves into the 21st century and recruit a more valuable and diverse viewpoint than the current old-boys club set-up. When nearly one in four firms only have one woman on their board, it’s clear that many of our biggest companies still have a long way to go. Business culture needs to change rapidly, to challenge existing stereotypes and to realise the positive impact on performance of greater diversity.”

Four FTSE 100 companies – the retailer Next, the online estate agent Rightmove, the financial services provider Hargreaves Lansdown and the builder Taylor Wimpey – have 50% or more women on their boards.

Greg Clark, the business secretary, said: “Many businesses have championed gender diversity, building on our modern industrial strategy’s ambition to ensure everyone can progress in the workplace. If companies are not diverse they are missing out on the benefits that a diverse workforce brings. Sadly, other companies are lagging behind and I want to see all of those companies do more to increase the number of women at the top.”

US stock markets dropped sharply on Monday as big technology companies led losses, and fears over an escalating trade war with China rattled investors. The Dow Jones Industrial Average briefly fell 500 points, ending the day down 396 points (1.56%).

Apple, Microsoft and Amazon, the most valuable companies on the market, sustained some of the worst losses. Apple dropped close to 4% on renewed worries that iPhone sales could slow and Amazon lost 5%. Facebook dropped 5.7% as the company continued to struggle with issues related to its reaction to the discovery of manipulation of its platform.

The arrest of Nissan chairman Carlos Ghosn on charges he underreported his income and misused company funds caused the company’s shares to tumble and shocked many in Japan who view him as something of a hero. US-traded shares of Nissan lost 5.8%, while Renault shares dropped 8.4% in Paris. In Asia, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 1% to 2,675.69 and Tokyo’s Nikkei 225 lost 0.9% to 21,633.54. Hong Kong’s Hang Seng retreated 1.3% to 26,023.02 and Seoul’s Kospi shed 0.7% to 2,086.50.

In Japan, chief cabinet secretary Yoshihide Suga said on Tuesday the government was watching for economic fallout from the scandal at one of the world’s biggest vehicle manufacturers.

The so-called Faang companies (Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix and Google) whose rises helped drive stock markets to record highs have all suffered sharp losses in recent weeks. Each is down more than 20% from its year high – technically known as a bear market.

“I’ve been looking for them to show some leadership which they fail to do, and until we get the tech leadership I think equities are going to continue to struggle,” said Peter Cecchini, the managing director at Cantor Fitzgerald in New York.

Related: Why are markets plunging and which stocks are worst hit?

The jittery trading came after two days of gains last week as investors hoped that the US and China were moving closer to settling their costly trade fight, which has been a major uncertainty for investors. Those hopes faded after the two countries clashed at a Pacific Rim summit over the weekend.

A steep loss for Boeing, a major exporter which would stand to suffer greatly in a protracted trade war, also weighed heavily on the Dow.

The S&P 500 index fell 44 points, or 1.6% while the tech-heavy Nasdaq lost 2.7%.

The disagreements between the US and China at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting left investors pessimistic about the prospects for a deal that would end trade tensions between the world’s two largest economies. For the first time in almost 30 years, leaders at the summit could not agree on a joint declaration on world trade.

Talks between the US and China are continuing ahead of a meeting between Xi Jinping, the Chinese president, and Donald Trump planned for the G20 summit later this month.

US stock markets continued to fall on Tuesday, wiping out all of 2018’s gains as a slide in technology stocks grew into a wider selloff and fears of a trade war with China worried investors.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 555 points in New York, a slide of 2.2% and the Nasdaq, home to Amazon, Facebook and many other tech giants, was down another 1.7% following sharper falls on Monday.

The leading tech companies have now lost a combined $1tn in value since their year highs.

But what started as a sell-off of high-flying tech companies spread on Tuesday as the oil price tumbled and investors sold investments in retailers, energy companies and bitcoin. US markets rallied briefly but have now erased all the gains they have made this year.

Analysts said there were likely to be more wild swings to come. “I don’t think Santa Claus is going to waltz in and give us a rally for Christmas,” said Michael Antonelli, managing director of institutional sales trading at Robert W Baird in Milwaukee.

The wider US economy still looks rosy. Unemployment is at levels unseen since the Vietnam war, business confidence is high and interest rates low despite a series of small increases. But stock markets are often a leading indicator of economic trends and investors see trouble ahead.

“Many of the metrics are already at the extremes,” said Jack Ablin, chief investment officer of Cresset Capital. “In many respects we are at the North Pole. No matter what step we take it’s going to be south.”

Much of the fall has been driven by troubles at the so-called Faang companies (Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Netflix and Google) whose phenomenal growth had driven stock markets to record highs.

August’s trillion-dollar headline was provided by Apple when it became the first company to achieve such a lofty stock market valuation. Amazon got there in September. October was a fallow month for trillion-dollar statistics but here comes November’s offering. The big five “Faang” companies – the other three initials provided by Facebook, Netflix and Google – have collectively shed $1tn in capitalisation from their high points this year. The sector has turned at spectacular speed.

It’s just a demonstration of the thrills and spills of investing in technology, it could be said. There’s something in that idea, of course, since nobody owns these stocks for a dull life. Investors are betting on fabulous rates of earnings growth, projected many years into the future. It only takes a modest shift in the financial weather for valuation to be whacked.

Yet tech stocks do not inhabit an entirely different investment universe. There are at least two reasons why the current tech rout may be signalling broader market worries.

First, investors may be looking at 2019 and deciding that the only way is slower for the global economy. One engine – the US – has been running in overdrive this year as President Trump’s tax cuts have fed into the system. That effect will fade and next year’s story will be the pace at which the US Federal Reserve lifts interest rates. There is a risk of the Fed doing too much, too soon. Meanwhile, the other global driver – China – is spluttering. A growth rate of 6.5% looks good from a western perspective but is the slowest since the 2008 financial crisis. There is nothing that will obviously improve next year’s outlook.

That is partly because of the second factor – the US-China trade war. “If you want a short-term solution, there is no solution,” said Jack Ma, the Alibaba billionaire in September, predicting 20 years of trade hostility. Investors didn’t want to believe it, but they’ve having to reassess.

Hopes of a truce at this month’s G20 are low and falling after US vice-president Mike Pence said at an Asia Pacific conference this week that the US “will not change course until China changes its ways”. Meanwhile, China has launched a high-profile price-fixing investigation into three big computer chip makers, including one US firm. That affair may be unrelated, but it clearly doesn’t make peace over intellectual property more likely. On current form, you’d bet that the next round of US tariff hikes – scheduled for January – will happen.

“All good things eventually come to an end,” said Goldman Sachs’ market analysts on Tuesday, striking a bearish tone in their predictions for 2019. “Cash will represent a competitive asset class to stocks for the first time in many years,” the Wall Street bank said. That is eye-catching, as end-of-year forecasts are supposed to be, but it reflects the suddenly downbeat mood. If Apple can no longer shift more iPhones at higher prices, which is the micro worry about the tech sector, something big may have changed.

Bumpy road ahead for Renault

The reaction of senior Renault executives to the arrest of Carlos Ghosn was fascinating. “On your behalf, we would like to state here our full support for our chairman and CEO,” wrote chief operating officer Thierry Bolloré to staff, before stating that “the governance bodies are playing their full role in defending Groupe Renault’s corporate interest”.

It’s not hard to read between the lines. On the Renault side, they clearly don’t trust the process by which Ghosn has been accused of under-reporting his income at Nissan and committing “numerous” misdeeds. And they clearly suspect this affair will turn into a battle for control of a three-way corporate alliance that also contains Mitsubishi.

One can understand Renault management’s suspicions. Nissan chief executive Hiroto Saikawa didn’t wait to hear if Ghosn denies the fraud charges. Nor did he attempt to explain if Nissan, or its auditors, could have been complicit in any alleged wrongdoing. He just seemed anxious to condemn the “negative” aspects of Ghosn’s regime and ignore the obvious questions about lax governance at Nissan itself.

If Renault’s top brass smell a power grab, you couldn’t blame them. Given the relative recent performance of the two companies, Renault, owner of 43% Nissan, desperately needs the partnership to hold. The FT’s revelation on Tuesday that Ghosn had been planning a merger between Renault and Nissan before his arrest in Tokyo, and that Japanese firm’s board was opposed, will only deepen tensions.

Good luck to the French government, owner of 15% of Renault. This tale looks set to become very messy very quickly.

The US-China trade standoff will continue to weaken confidence in the global economy into next year, economists have warned, as the increasingly gloomy outlook for growth dragged on share markets across the world.

Plunging oil prices and intensifying concerns about technology stocks in the US spread contagion to Asia Pacific markets on Wednesday after renewed losses on Wall Street.

Related: Why central bank digital currencies will destroy bitcoin | Nouriel Roubini

But as the broad losses in Wall Street pulled its key indices into the red for this year, economists at JP Morgan warned that the trade dispute between the world’s two biggest economies threatens more trouble ahead.

“We forecast that the US imposes an additional 25% tariff on virtually all goods imports from China early next year. This will drag materially on activity in China and could accelerate the decline in global business confidence now underway,” the JP Morgan team wrote in a note to clients.

Although they forecast that the Chinese authorities will throw more policy stimulus to offset a hit from the tariffs and keep GDP growth at 6%, the team predicted that markets must prepare for the Federal Reserve to raise borrowing costs another four times next year.

The prospect of more rate hikes will set alarms bells ringing in emerging markets, which have already been squeezed of liquidity by the rise of the US dollar over the past few months.

Stocks from Sydney to Shanghai were in the red on Wednesday afternoon, although they had pared earlier, heavier losses. The Nikkei in Tokyo was off 0.3% while the Australian benchmark index dropped 1.2% in the morning to a fresh 21-month low.

Oil prices, which dropped 6% on Tuesday, pushed energy stocks lower as investors fretted about weaker global growth and specualtion about the end of the tech stock boom. Brent crude was up 1.2% in early trade on Wednesday.

Soichiro Monji, senior economist at Daiwa SB Investments in Tokyo, told Reuters: “It is difficult to pinpoint a single factor driving the global risk aversion. Apple and trade tensions seem to be touted as factors every other day, but it is difficult to blame them for all the woes.

“The markets appear to be starting to prepare for a loss of momentum in the global economy, although it is doing quite well at the moment.”

Related: CBA chair admits board and management failures at banking royal commission – live

Plummeting oil prices – weakened by wider uncertainty in global shares – had hurt Australian energy stocks, with the sector dropping by more than 3% early on. The Aussie dollar had slipped to US72.14c overnight but recovered to US72.37c.

The falls come as two closely watched indicators survey pointed to trouble ahead for the Australian economy.

The Westpac–Melbourne Institute leadingindex, which indicates the likely pace of economic activity three to nine months into the future, fell from 0.41% in September to just 0.08% in October.

Westpac’s chief economist, Bill Evans, said: “With this latest slowdown, the index growth rate continues to point to slowing momentum into the new year.

Related: 'Epidemic of time theft': Australians work two months' unpaid overtime a year

He blamed weak wages growth, falling property prices in Sydney and Melbourne and a very low savings rate for the poor outlook for consumer spending.

In addition, the NAB monthly cashless retail sales index published on Wednesday said data mapping suggested that the official Australia Bureau of Statistics measure of retail sales would grow at a worse-than-expected 0.2% month-on-month in October.

The big four banks were all down, with the losses led by ANZ, which posted a 0.77% drop to $25.105. Commonwealth Bank, whose chair, Catherine Livingstone, was on the stand at the banking royal commission on Wednesday morning, fell 0.6%. Tech shares continued to fall, losing more than 2.8% early, with telco stocks also down.

Australian Associated Press and Reuters contributed to this report.

Black Friday, Britain’s biggest shopping event, is nearly upon us, and with many high street retailers struggling, shoppers can expect to bag some good bargains.

It originated in the US, where stores mark the start of the festive shopping season the day after the Thanksgiving public holiday with big price cuts and promotions.

It has become a fortnight-long £10bn shopping extravaganza, while some retailers, including Carphone Warehouse and Halfords, offer Black Friday-themed discounts for all of November.

Amazon fired the starting gun a week early and is billing this year’s wave of promotions as its “biggest-ever Black Friday sale”. It has tens of thousands of “lightning deals” that offer bargains in limited quantities.

Related: Amazon and high street chains kick off Black Friday early

Much of the shopping will be done online again, with shoppers preferring to bargain hunt on their phones or laptops, rather than queuing up outside shops in the early hours. However, some offers can only be had in stores, for example, at Morrisons.

Related: Black Friday: stay out of the red with our smart shopping guide

Here is the Observer’s handy guide to how to snap up a bargain and stay out of the red.

Consumer experts advise shopping around (you can use comparison websites such as idealo or Amazon price tracker Camelcamelcamel) and checking retailers’ returns policies before buying.

Here’s what the retailers are offering – we’ll update it as new deals come in.

What’s happening? Amazon’s 10-day Black Friday sale runs until 25 November. There is also a pop-up event in east London on 22-25 November, with prize giveaways and cocktail, jewellery and candle-making workshops (doors open for 24 hours on Black Friday).

Where? Go to Amazon’s Black Friday page.

What? There will be “deals of the day” and “lightning deals” – products that are discounted for a short period of time.

The biggest reductions include a 55in Philips 4K Ultra HD TV for £1,199 – a £300 discount – and more than £100 off De’Longhi coffee machines.

Where? Find out more here.

What? Promotions include a Lenovo 15.6in laptop reduced by £30 to £269 and a Toshiba smart 4K ultra-HD TV discounted by £90 to £279.

Argos

What’s happening? Argos launched its discounts on 16 November.

Where? The Argos Black Friday website is here.

What? Deals include 30% off Hive smart cameras at £129 and a Fitbit Blaze smart watch for £109, reduced by £20.

What’s happening? Asda has rejoined the Black Friday party with a fortnight of promotions that run until 27 December and are billed as “green is the new black”.

Where? Online promotions can be found here.

What? Offers include a Little Tikes Stem Jr WonderLab reduced by £30 to £60; a Hot Wheels slot track set for £45, down from £74.87; and an Oral-B toothbrush for £50, down from £98.

What’s happening? The online fashion retailer has knocked 20% off everything with the code HELLO20.

Where? Find out more here.

What’s happening? The bed retailer’s sale runs until 27 November.

Where? In stores; online deals can be found here.

What’s happening? Body Shop offers 40% off hundreds of items and 25% off gifts on its website, with the code 19805.

Where? Go to the website.

What? Promotions include an online-only Black Friday bundle for £40 (worth £88).

What’s happening? The online fashion retailer is offering big discounts on dresses.

Where? Find out more on the website.

What? There are discounts of 30% to 88% on dresses, for example a Holly one-shoulder bodycon dress now sells for £31.

Cyber Monday, one of the busiest online shopping days of the year, marks the end of a fortnight-long, £10bn shopping bonanza.

Where? Cyber Monday deals can be found here.

What? Amazon is knocking up to 35% off beauty gift sets from Olay, Elemis and Burt’s Bees; up to 50% off perfumes including Jimmy Choo and Diesel; up to 30% off toy cars; and up to 25% off Maxi-Cosi car seats and accessories.

webTitle: Cyber Monday 2018: guide to the best UK deals and offers

fields.body:
4.07pm GMT

So I’m shortly going to be wrapping this live blog up - see what I did there - but here’s a reminder of some of the main Cyber Monday deals you can get with some of the UK’s biggest retailers today:

Amazon UK

What’s happening? The online retailer is offering “lightning deals” of discounted products that usually run for six hours on Cyber Monday, as well as deals of the day.

Where? Cyber Monday deals can be found here.

Argos

What’s happening? Like many retailers, Argos has rolled Cyber Monday into its Black Friday sales.

Where? The Argos Black Friday page is updated with what is left in stock for Cyber Monday.

What? Customers can save 20% on selected homewares by quoting HOME20 and save 20% when they spend £100 or more on selected indoor furniture by quoting FURN20.

Asos

What’s happening? The online fashion retailer is offering 20% off everything.

Where? Find out more here.

Debenhams

What’s happening? The Debenhams 12-day sale runs until 1 December.

Where? The online sale is here.

What? There are half-price women’s, men’s and kids’ boots, up to half price on beauty, perfumes and electrical devices; and 40% off women’s and kids’ knitwear.

eBay

What’s happening? eBay has a sale until 30 November.

Where? You can find offers here.

Etsy

Etsy has gathered together all the items with Cyber Monday discounts on their site into one place. There’s a huge range of discounted jewellery and clothing, on offer, and it’s also a good chance to pick up a few bits to make your home even more festive with a range of discounted Christmas decorations on offer.

Gap

What’s happening? Gap is offering 50% off full-price items and an extra 25% off sale styles until Tuesday.

Where? Go to the website and use the code CYBERGAP.

Habitat

What’s happening? Habitat’s “black five days” take in Cyber Monday.

Where? Online offers are here.

Hamleys

What’s happening? Hamleys offers savings of up to 50% on hundreds of toys and games on Cyber Monday.

Where? The online sale is here.

Harvey Nichols

What’s happening? A Black Friday/Cyber Weekend/Cyber Monday sale running from 23 November to 26 November, both online and in-store.

Where? You can find the discounts here.

What? Up to 25% off fashion and accessories, and 10% off beauty.

House of Fraser

What’s happening? The department store chain is offering up to 60% off across fashion, home and beauty, on Cyber Monday.

Where? Online promotions can be found here.

John Lewis

What’s happening? They say they have lowered hundreds of their prices “even further”.

Where? The discounts are gathered together here.

What? Offers include discounts on Mulberry and UGG, as well as deals on Apple, Samsung and Sonos products.

Liberty

What’s happening? Liberty have been running “The event before Christmas” which ends today.

What? Up to 30% off, with 15% off beauty. The deals aren’t grouped together as easily as on other websites though, so you have to have a bit of a rummage through the men’s, women’s and kid’s sections to bargain hunt.

Mothercare

What’s happening? Mothercare’s big sale finishes on Cyber Monday.

Where? Online deals are here.

What? There are discounts of up to 60% on all toys, up to 50% off some car seats, bedding and nursery furniture; and 25% off all clothing, footwear and accessories.

Notonthehighstreet

What’s happening? The online marketplace is offering savings of up to 50% on thousands of products.

Where? On the website.

Ocado

What’s happening? Ocado has half-price or better offers until midnight.

Where? Ocado’s Cyber Monday page is here.

What? Deals include a Philips Sonicare Diamond clean electric toothbrush for £99.99, down from £299; and a 75cl bottle of Champagne Autréau Brut Prestige Les Perles de la Dhuy Grand Cru 2011 for £26.66, down from £39.99.

Red Bubble

Red Bubble has a wide variety of goods and unique designs, and for Cyber Monday they are offering 30% off everything. Use the code 30CYBER at the checkout to access the deals.

Sainsbury’s

What’s happening? Sainsbury’s has knocked 25% off all Tu clothing and has deals on its entire range, from groceries to electronics.

Where? The Tu promotion can be found here.

Ted Baker

What’s happening? Ted Baker’s technology partner, Proporta, will be offering up to 60% off on its website.

Where? The Cyber Week sale runs from 26 November until 3 December here.

Updated at 5.14pm GMT

4.05pm GMT

Some new research by Barclaycard has suggested that this year in the UK we will spend £1.6bn on experience gifts this Christmas, as people veer away from sending and receiving physical gifts, and look towards presents that can make memories. And are also super-Instagram material.

Barclaycard also say that their consumer survey suggested that this year spending in the Xmas period itself on entertainment and events such as gigs, beauty treatments and adventure days will be up 115% on last year

If you are thinking of gifting someone an experience, then there are some deals around today that can save you a bit of cash - and they’ll never know you skimped by ordering it on Cyber Monday ;-)

Virgin Experience Days are offering a selection of deals as part of their Cyber Weekend promotion. It is worth having a dig around the full list, but here are some of the highlights:

  • 50% off the View from The Shard Experience for two adults (Now £32, was £64)
  • 75% off a Winery and Brewery Tour for two with tastings (Now £7.50, was £30)
  • 35% off a London Bungee Jump for one (Now £49, was £80)
  • 25% off a Vintage Afternoon Tea Bus Tour for two (Now £82.50, was £110)
  • 60% off a Supercar experience in 24 locations across the UK (Now £55, was £139)

There also some deals on London Musicals

  • Aladdin in the West End is offering tickets from £25 as a limited Black Friday weekend promotion, with savings on tickets of up to 39%.
  • Kinky Boots tickets are on sale for up to 43% off from lastminute.com and Encore Tickets, starting at a very reasonable £17.50.
  • Dreamgirls at the Savoy Theatre is another production that is taking part in Cyber Monday deals (which last until 30 November), with savings of up to 28% on tickets within the C and D price bands plus no booking fee.
  • Motown The Musical has deals on tickets for up to 46% off (starting at £21.50), and they have also taken the cost of booking fees off orders made for performances between 22nd - 29th December.

4.02pm GMT

It would be remiss of me to spend a whole day live blogging special Cyber Monday offers and then neglect to mention one rather close to home...

The Guardian and The Observer

What’s happening? Brilliant offers across our range of print and digital subscription packages

Where’s it happening? You can become a subscriber here.

What’s the deal? Save 50% for three months on print and digital subscriptions to The Guardian and The Observer. Offer ends Sunday 2 December.

3.22pm GMT

If you are in the market for smart watches, then there are some good deals kicking around today on the web.

You can save £60 on the Apple Watch Series 3 over at John Lewis, while Withings are offering their Full Black Smart Watch at half-price.

There’s a decent (if slightly exaggerated) price drop on Huawei Band 2 Pro Fitness Wristband at Amazon, and you can also get the Fitbit Unisex Versa Health and Fitness Smartwatch for £159 from the online retail giant. The Garmin Fenix 5 Multisport GPS Watch also has a hefty online discount on it at the moment, bringing it down to £309.99.

3.12pm GMT

As one of the Guardian’s resident Doctor Who nerds there was absolutely no way I was going to get through live blogging Cyber Monday without somehow cramming a Cyberman reference in there. And it is even topical, because episode Kerblam! the other week was about the perils of working in a mostly-automated factory sending out parcels and gifts. Ahem.

Fortunately there are some Doctor Who-related deals I can tell you about. Big Finish, who produce Doctor Who audio dramas based on the original series, often with the original actors, have been offering discounts on a range of titles featuring the Time Lord’s Fantastic Foes, including the Master, the Daleks, the Ice Warriors, and of course, the Cybermen. Access the deals here using the code FANTASTIC.

If you are buying for someone whose cult interests go a bit further than Doctor Who, then it is worth dropping in on the Forbidden Planet special offers page - they have discounts on a range of about 50 items including merchandise for Harry Potter, Rick & Morty, Star Wars, and Deadpool.

3.00pm GMT

One of the things I suggested in my piece today about thoughtful presents you’ve still got time to make or order was using old photos to make a nostalgic present for relatives or old friends. And you can do that slightly cheaper today, as printing service Photobox are offering up to 50% off everything, with an additional 20% off if you use the code CYBER20. Unfortunately you can’t get a 20% discount on the amount of time it takes you to sort out the mess of photos stored on your laptop.

2.48pm GMT

Shopping online isn’t without potential pitfalls, and Hannah Maundrell, Editor in Chief of online comparison service money.co.uk, has this advice for people doing their Christmas shopping today.

She says shoppers should “factor in the cost of delivery when you compare prices online. Check whether you can click and collect for free, as this can be a good way to save if you live near a store.”

She also warns us to be on our guard, saying “just because a retailer tells you they’ve cut the price of an item you can’t take it as gospel; you’ll only know it’s good value by shopping around. Be suspicious and check.”

And there is a reminder of the consumer rights you enjoy when ordering online: “You get 14 days from the day your order arrives to return it and get a refund. This gives you the flexibility to cancel if you find your bargain cheaper elsewhere. There are some exceptions, like personalised goods, but it’s guaranteed on most other purchases.”

If possible, she says, “pay for items that cost over £100 by credit card to get protection, so you can go to your credit card company for a refund if there’s an issue.”

Her final warning is one that applies to virtually everything on the internet, whether it is fake news or a Cyber Monday bargain: “If a deal seems too good to be true, treat it with a healthy degree of uncertainty.”

2.39pm GMT

One of the things about Christmas is that it inevitably leads into the new year, and grand plans to re-invent yourself into a healthier lifestyle. What if you could prepare for that moment in advance? Here’s how you can do that, and save a little bit of money as well, with Cyber Monday deals on subscription boxes.

HelloFresh is a subscription service that allows you to download the app and pick from a selection of recipes each week to be delivered to your door in neat packages with all of the fiddly ingredients portioned out and prepared for you. They often have good introductory deals, but their Cyber Weekend deal takes it one step further, offering 55% off your first 2 boxes/weeks (and you are not obliged to continue your subscription).

Birchbox are offering 2 boxes for £5 using the code FRIYAY, a promotion they claim is their “best offer ever.” Usually, boxes are £10 each, making this a 75% discount. Plus, December’s box will have a bumper 7 products, and again, the subscription can be cancelled at any time.

KiwiCo deliver monthly crates of educational and creative activities for kids of “every age and interest” and they are currently offering 60% off the first crate for those who sign up on Cyber Monday.

Lifebox are part of the “Wellness Revolution”, delivering a selection of superfood snacks to subscribers every month as a “convenient and affordable way of discovering new and delicious wholefoods.” You can also buy their boxes as a one-off, and for Black Friday they are reducing the price of their Classic and Energy boxes to £17.21 (was £22.95).

Updated at 2.40pm GMT

1.49pm GMT

With about ten hours of Cyber Monday still to go, here’s a summary of some of the best deal lists we’ve posted so far:

  • Video games and consoles
  • Major UK retailers
  • Smart speakers and home voice assistants
  • Phones and phone accessories
  • Homeware deals
  • Flights and holidays
  • Museums and attractions

Plus we’ve covered magazine subscriptions, books, vacuum cleaners and kitchen mixers among other things.

I’m also interested in you sending me any weird and super-niche Cyber Monday offers by email to martin.belam@theguardian.com.

1.39pm GMT

Pro-tip 1: Don’t buy your partner gadgets to do household chores as Christmas presents.

Pro-tip 2: If you need a new household chore gadget anyway, today is a good day to buy it cheaper than usual.

Here’s a selection of deals on vacuum cleaners:

DYSON V7 Motorhead Cordless, Bagless Vacuum Cleaner

Peddler are offering up to 37% off the Dyson V7 Motorhead Vacuum Cleaner, bringing it down from £370 to £234.19. However, if you would make use of Dyson’s ‘Toolkit’ including additional tools for mattresses, hard-to-reach areas and dried in dirt, Currys PC World are offering the Dyson V7 Motorhead Vacuum in a bundle deal with the Dyson Handheld Toolkit for a combined price of £249.

iRobot Roomba 980 Vacuum Cleaner

Save £50 on the iRobot Roomba at John Lewis & Partners, making it £799, and get a 2 year guarantee included. Also good fun if you’ve got cats or dogs round the house.

SHARK IF250UKT True Pet Cordless Vacuum Cleaner

Currys PC World have reduced this Shark vacuum cleaner to £279 (was £479) in their Cyber Monday sale. Plus, you can utilise another discount code on top of this promotion, which takes 10% off the marked price when you quote VACUUM10 at checkout, and there is the option to pay monthly.

VAX Air Lift Steerable Pet Max Upright Bagless Vacuum Cleaner

This well-reviewed vacuum cleaner has been reduced by several retailers with a saving of around £50, to £129. However, John Lewis & Partners and Currys PC World are both offering an included 2 year guarantee in their deals.

Miele Classic C1 Edition Powerline Bagged Vacuum Cleaner

With a saving of £51, the Miele Classic C1 Edition Vacuum is now £99 at John Lewis & Partners, who claim this deal is ‘exclusive’ to their customers. Like the other John Lewis deals mentioned, this also comes with a 2 year guarantee included and the option to add further protection against accidental damage for £10.

Happy holiday hoovering!

1.14pm GMT

The chances are that you’ll be in charge of buying the presents for at least one football fanatic in the family, and football merchandise is an easy, if obvious, choice for those sometimes-hard-to-buy-for children.

Going to club websites today will yield you some savings. At the top of the Premier League Manchester City, Liverpool, Spurs, Chelsea, Arsenal and Everton are all offering discounts on selected lines ranging from 20% at Chelsea to 50% at Arsenal. A quick trip down the leagues showed club shops from the likes of Leeds and Sunderland joining in, so it’s worth checking directly with clubs to see if there is a deal on.

Even my beloved Leyton Orient have some special offers on, so maybe it is finally the year someone will get me a nice woolly hat to wear at Brisbane Road.

12.52pm GMT

As a nation we are still in the grip of bake-off fever, which means the market for kitchen gadgets has never been healthier or more competitive. Here are some deals on stand mixers if you are looking to “soup” up your kitchen gear. You see what I did there.

KitchenAid 150 Artisan 4.8L Stand Mixer

For anyone who has been waiting to get their hands on the cult favourite KitchenAid Artisan mixer - now is the time. This mixer has been dramatically reduced by several retailers, but most notably, Currys have reduced their price from £549.99 to £274 (a £275.99 saving). Plus, they are offering a further discount code giving customers 10% off their order when they spend over £200 on 2 or more small kitchen appliances and there is also the option to pay monthly.

Kenwood kMix KMX754 Stand Mixer

The Kenwood kMix has also seen large reductions across the board - AO, Amazon and John Lewis have all reduced their prices to £179. However, John Lewis include a 2 year guarantee with their deal, and you can add an additional 2 years of protection against accidental damage for £15.

Fearne by Swan: 6 Litre Die Cast Stand Mixer

After bringing out several successful cookbooks, Fearne Cotton released her own range of kitchen appliances with Swan. Her 6 Litre stand mixer has not been reduced by many retailers, but Amazon are offering a saving of £175, making it £124.99 (down from £299.99) in four colours, and they are also including free delivery.

Sage The Scraper Mixer BEM430

Heston Blumenthal’s 4.7L stand mixer is on offer at almost 30% off from ECookshop, with free delivery available. While this is a better deal than the likes of AO and Amazon are offering, if you do spot it cheaper elsewhere, ECookshop will endeavour to price match.

Also, while we are thinking about the kitchen, do take five minutes to read Zoe Williams’ amazing interview with bake-off’s Kim-Joy

Related: ‘I was pretty much mute at school’: how Bake Off’s Kim-Joy found happiness

Updated at 12.53pm GMT

12.45pm GMT

Running a live blog about Cyber Monday is a bit like going shopping, but without any of the fun. And by the end of the day I won’t have got my Christmas shopping sorted either. However, it does mean you run into a lot of rather leftfield suggestions for ways for people to invest and save money.

Probably the most obscure promo I’ve seen cross my inbox so far today is for Farmers Weekly. They’ve extended their weekend sale and today, for the last day, you can subscribe to the Web+ digital version of Farmers Weekly for £50+VAT. Go on, you know you want to.

It’s not the only place you can get subscription discounts on magazines however. Magazine.co.uk is offering £15 off when you subscribe to three titles. iSubscribe, on the other hand, is offering 10% off and a £5 credit voucher if you take out magazine subscriptions before the end of today. GreatMagazines.co.uk is offering 20% off new subscriptions over the value of £25, and that deal runs until the end of tomorrow.

Another magazine with a special deal going on is Anorak, the ‘happy mag for kids’ aimed at boys and girls aged between 6 and 12 years old. They are offering 20% off all their single issues and posters with the code HAPPYANORAK. You can have a browse here.

Incidentally, you can email me at martin.belam@theguardian.com if you’ve seen an even more obscure Cyber Monday deal.

Updated at 1.18pm GMT

12.27pm GMT

Books make a lovely gift, since the choice often says something personal about you, and there are some bargains to be had out there on Cyber Monday.

WH Smith are offering 50% off or more on selected titles and Waterstones have a similar deal, while Book Depository have up to 60% off their promotional titles. You can get 20% off online purchases at Foyles with the code BLACKFRIDAY20. CYBER25 is the code you need to unlock 25% discounts with Book People.

Don’t forget that the Guardian Bookshop is also offering deals and gift suggestions with up to 30% discount, which you can find here.

Need a bit of inspiration? Here’s what our books team were recommending back in the autumn.

Related: The 50 biggest books of autumn 2018

12.05pm GMT

Cyber Monday Homeware deals

West Elm are offering 20% off everything in stock, including items that are already in clearance, quoting the puntastic code “FRIYAY” in store or online. They are also featuring 40% off bonus deals for certain collections including flannel bed linen, square dinnerware, mongolian cushion covers, terrariums and more.

Habitat have savings “across 100s of lines” until midnight tonight, letting customers know that “today is your last chance to bag a seriously good deal.” Unlike many of their counterparts, Habitat are not using a blanket percentage off, and instead have specific deals on certain lines. For example:

  • Save £1000 on selected mattresses
  • Save up to £750 off Hendricks fabric sofas
  • Save £100 on the Jacobs Storage Bench
  • Save £30 on bed linen

Anthropologie have 20% discounts on selected lines until midnight tonight. From their House & Home lines, selected mugs, glasses, plates, candles are reduced.

Made.com are offering free delivery until midnight tonight, and other selected promotions, including:

  • £100 off when you buy a bed and mattress
  • A ‘last chance’ up to 20% off on selected items including beds, sofas, lighting and more

Swoon are throwing “a farewell party for designs we’ll never make again” by offering up to 70% off on 100+ designs. Whilst several of the items are already selling out, some of the remaining deals include:

  • Maija Pendant lights in black (Was £79, now £24)
  • Liza cabinet (Was £529, now £264)
  • Chapo mirror (Was £229, now £171)
  • Ginsberg bench (Was £270, now £140)
  • Ancona shelving unit (Was £549, now £329)

DFS are offering several deals today which, despite the endless internet jokes about endless DFS sales, will end at midnight. They include up to half price off their Autumn/Winter collection, and up to £350 savings when you purchase an Exclusive Brand product and any other item.

H&M Home are running a Cyber Monday promotion which gives customers up to 50% off selected items until midnight tonight, and an additional 10% off for H&M Club members. They are also offering free standard delivery on all orders which will be automatically applied at checkout.

Other homewares brands that are offering Cyber Monday discounts include Wayfair, Debenhams, and Sofa.com.

And with that, I’m going to pop to have some lunch at the Guardian canteen, where I’m hoping there will be some cracking Cyber Monday deals on quinoa and hummus.

11.50am GMT

Cyber Monday deals on phones and phone accessories

For the Apple iPhone XR, while Carphone Warehouse are offering a saving of £470 on the a 24 month Vodafone contract for the iPhone XR until midnight (£36 per month, £59.99 upfront cost), mobiles.co.uk are offering the same deal except with no upfront cost.

If it is the Google Pixel you are after, Carphone Warehouse are also offering £510 off their Google Pixel 3 24 month contract with Vodafone, including 100GB of data and unlimited texts and minutes (£36 per month, £29.99 upfront cost)

Mobilephonesdirect.co.uk’s top deal for Cyber Monday is a 24 month contract for the Huawei Mate 20 Pro (128GB) at £45 a month with no upfront cost. This deal comes with 50GB data, unlimited minutes and texts, an O2 SIM card, free delivery and one month’s free insurance.

Appliances Direct meanwhile have dramatically reduced the price of the Samsung Galaxy S9 by £240, making it £499. Mobiles.co.uk are pushing several extended deals for Cyber Monday. Among other things they are offering an iPhone XR on Vodafone with 100GB data for £36 per month and a Samsung Galaxy S9 on Vodafone with 40GB data in a deal which works out to £28 per month.

In the market for an iPhone XS? In among the buymobiles.net Cyber Monday offers you can pick one up for £37 per month with 80GB of data. There’s an upfront cost of £119, but it looks to be one of the better deals for that handset today.

On the accessories front, Gear4 have big discounts on protective cases for your phones, including 70% off the Piccadilly range and 50% off the Battersea range, which will apparently protect your phone from a 16 foot drop. Screen protectors for the Apple iPhone 6/7/8, iPhone X/XS, iPhone XS Max and iPhone XR are down to £20.99 from £29.99.

Updated at 11.59am GMT

11.44am GMT

If skin care is your thing, then hop over to the Dermalogica website where for Cyber Monday they are offering three for two on full-sized products.

Feel Unique, meanwhile, have a range of Cyber Monday deals promising up to 33% off of over 25,000 beauty and perfume products, and the exciting bonus of a mystery gift if you spend over £50. *spooky ooo-oooo-oh ghost noise*

11.28am GMT

One big question around Black Friday and Cyber Monday that remains - is it actually making anybody any happier?

A couple of days ago my colleague reported on whether the backlash against Black Friday had already started in the UK. Greenpeace is among a group of organisations promoting MAKE SMTHNG as an alternative to the consumer spending over this weekend. During it artists and crafters run workshops on ways to reuse, repair or recycle goods, rather than buying something new.

Related: Has the backlash to Black Friday already started?

There is some data too about how the Black Friday shopping experience makes people unhappy. HappyOrNot, the company that produce the little machines where you can register how happy you are with a consumer experience by pressing a range of smiley or not-smiley faces, measured 575,000 feedbacks from customers in places like Lidl, Zara, and Tesco. They claim that analysing the data shows that we’ve just lived through the unhappiest UK Black Friday they have on record.

As well as a year-on-year decline in happiness, in the UK, Black Friday was slightly unhappier (79.8%) for UK shoppers than an average day in 2018 (80.3%). UK shopper happiness also dropped drastically throughout the day, starting at 84.3% for early birds at 9am, and ending at 78% for those still slogging round the shops at 9pm.

None of that today though - with Cyber Monday you can happily do it all from your phone of course.

11.03am GMT

By the way, if you are struggling for Christmas inspiration, we have this year’s gift guide over here.

Related: The Christmas gift guide: 100 great buys for every budget

And here are 12 ideas for gifts that keep giving throughout the year, by taking out a subscription service for someone.

10.48am GMT

Smart speaker Cyber Monday deals

The jury is still out on whether having a smart speaker in your home is giving corporations undue surveillance in our private spaces, or whether all that worry is out-weighed by it just really being handy to be able to shout out “Hey, whatsisface, play my electronic surveillance playlist, ta”, or turn the lights off without getting off the sofa.

If you are in the market for one, here are some options:

Amazon have a range of discounts on their home speaker products, including £35 off the Echo, £30 off the Echo Dot, and £30 off the second generation Echo Plus.

Google offer a variety of smart speakers and their flagship Google Home Hub. You can pick the latter up with a £40 discount from ao.com, which brings the price down to £99.

Currys PC World are also offering deals across the whole range of voice assistants.

Related: Google Home Hub review: the smart display to buy

10.24am GMT

Museums and attractions - Cyber Monday deals

Amidst the frenzy of Black Friday and Cyber Monday, there’s been a move in the US to try and get “Museum Sunday” to be a thing in the middle of it, where people promote more thoughtful activities than shopping. Although, obviously, getting people to part with their cash to attend attractions is still part of the agenda. It hasn’t particularly caught on in the UK yet, but there are some deals around on museums and attractions if you know where to look.

If Lego is your thing, then Legoland in Windsor have a new Haunted House Monster Party Ride launching in spring 2019, and some Cyber Monday offers on booking for it in advance. The deal works out at £35 per person based on a family of two adults and two children, and can be accessed here before midnight. When it presumably turns into a Lego pumpkin or something.

A Merlin Annual Pass can get you into 32 UK attractions including Madame Tussauds, the London Eye, Alton Towers, Sea Life centres and Warwick Castle. They are offering three months for free, making it last 15 months, if you order during their Cyber week offer. It could make a great gift for a family - but there’s quite a bit of small print to note though, and lots of times when you might want to be taking the kids out, like August and Bank Holidays, are excluded from the major attractions.

Not a visit, but the Natural History Museum have been running Black Friday and Cyber Monday discounts in their online store all weekend.

If there’s a transport nerd in your life, then the Black Friday sale at the London Transport Museum might be worth a visit - among the offers there’s a range of reproduction vintage posters down to half-price.

Oh, and if you do want an educational angle on Black Friday, this article from the Museum of London about how a march on Parliament by suffragettes on 18 November 1910 came to be known as Black Friday due to the repeated assaults on the protesting women might make an antidote to the spending it has come to be associated with today.

Updated at 10.30am GMT

10.01am GMT

Cyber Monday deals on flights and holidays

As well as offers on hotels, airlines often join in Black Friday and Cyber Monday with a series of deals to help you jet away in the new year.

British Airways have offers on luxury holidays which expire at midnight tonight, including saving £100 on holidays with a minimum spend of £2,500 per booking, and saving £50 on holidays with a minimum spend of £1,250 per booking. Which don’t seem like huge savings to be honest.

Club Med’s Cyber Monday promotion boasts that holidaymakers can save up to £520 per person on all-inclusive holidays. Destinations include skiing in the French Alps and holidays in the Caribbean, covering flights that depart from London, Manchester, Birmingham, Edinburgh and more.

Expedia claim to have secured “special low Black Friday & Cyber Monday fares from top airlines” - they’ve gathered the details here.

Fleetway also have some deals on flights and holidays - some of the options are gathered together here. There’s also a £100 discount on all holidays over £1200 if you enter the code BLACKFRIDAY when booking before 29 November.

Norwegian, the low-cost long-haul airline, have up to 30% off flights booked before the end of the day - it might finally be the moment to book that trip to the US.

Ryanair have a slightly more convoluted deal going on. If you book a room somewhere with them, you get 10% of the vale back as “Flight credit” on your account that you can then, presumably, spend on the flights to get there. There’s also a more straightforward £30 off flights offer.

Virgin Atlantic are offering up to £150 off flight and hotel combinations, you need to enter the code BF2018 when booking.

Updated at 1.22pm GMT

9.35am GMT

The shift to online retailing has made times tough on the high street for department stores. Harvey Nichols What’s happening? A Black Friday/Cyber Weekend/Cyber Monday sale running from 23 November to 26 November, both online and in-store. Where? You can find the discounts here. What? The online fashion retailer is offering 20% off everything. Where? Find out more here. Debenhams What’s happening? The Debenhams 12-day sale runs until 1 December. Where? The online sale is here. Where? You can find offers here. Gap What’s happening? Gap is offering 50% off full-price items and an extra 25% off sale styles until Tuesday. Where? Go to the website and use the code CYBERGAP. Habitat What’s happening? Habitat’s “black five days” take in Cyber Monday. Where? Online offers are here. Hamleys What’s happening? Hamleys offers savings of up to 50% on hundreds of toys and games on Cyber Monday. Where? The online sale is here. House of Fraser What’s happening? The department store chain is offering up to 60% off across fashion, home and beauty, on Cyber Monday. Where? Online promotions can be found here. Mothercare What’s happening? Mothercare’s big sale finishes on Cyber Monday. Where? Online deals are here. What? There are discounts of up to 60% on all toys, up to 50% off some car seats, bedding and nursery furniture; and 25% off all clothing, footwear and accessories. Notonthehighstreet What’s happening? The online marketplace is offering savings of up to 50% on thousands of products. Where? On the website. Ocado What’s happening? Ocado has half-price or better offers until midnight. Where? Ocado’s Cyber Monday page is here. What? Deals include a Philips Sonicare Diamond clean electric toothbrush for £99.99, down from £299; and a 75cl bottle of Champagne Autréau Brut Prestige Les Perles de la Dhuy Grand Cru 2011 for £26.66, down from £39.99. Sainsbury’s What’s happening? Sainsbury’s has knocked 25% off all Tu clothing and has deals on its entire range, from groceries to electronics. Where? The Tu promotion can be found here. Ted Baker What’s happening? Ted Baker’s technology partner, Proporta, will be offering up to 60% off on its website. Where? The Cyber Week sale runs from 26 November until 3 December here. Good morning. If you didn’t quite get all your Christmas shopping done on Black Friday then don’t worry - Black Friday’s younger cousin, Cyber Monday, is here. With a little bit of judicious online shopping today you can get Christmas done and dusted, and have the whole of December to just kick back and eat mince pies, safe in the knowledge all your gift shopping is done. fields.body:
John Lewis smashed its sales records last week, booking its biggest week ever as shoppers snapped up Black Friday deals on gadgets, beauty products, clothing and beds fuelled demand.

The department store chain said sales were up 7.7% in the week to 27 November on the same period last year, with sales in the fashion and beauty department up 13.1%.

John Lewis highlighted the super-luxury Creed Aventus perfume – which sells at £170 for a 50ml bottle – as a particularly big seller, along with its beauty advent calendar, which was reduced from £165 to £115.50 for Black Friday. Branded fashion also sold well.

Electrical and homeware sales were up nearly 6%, with bestsellers including Apple Airpods and smart speakers such as the Amazon Echo Dot and the Google Home Mini.

John Lewis said both its stores and website traded well with some stores also reporting a record week. Black Friday, the US-inspired discount event, was the busiest day but business was more broadly spread across the week than in previous years, as the company launched its own discounts earlier in the week and matched the promotional prices of rival stores under its “never knowingly undersold” pledge.

The strong figures from John Lewis will raise hopes of a better than expected Christmas for the retailer after early data for Black Friday, which fell on 23 November, suggested shoppers had cut back this year.

Barclaycard said that shoppers had spent 10% less on the day by mid-afternoon, while footfall in town centres, shopping centres and retail parks was down by 6%, according to the shopper monitoring firm Springboard. Part of that change was because shoppers were able to spread their bargain hunting over a longer period of time because retailers began discounting earlier.

Figures from the CBI, released on Tuesday, revealed that overall retail sales increased last month, especially at supermarkets and at shops selling household and recreational goods.

Analysts said the pick-up in sales was better than expected after a poor October when sales dropped to their weakest level since last April.

But the amount of goods sold dropped in shops selling clothing, footwear, furniture and carpets, and in hardware and DIY stores.

And the broadly healthier picture in November after a weak October was unable to prevent an eighth quarter in a row of declining employment across the retail sector.

Anna Leach, the CBI head of economic intelligence, said: “While it is encouraging to see headline retail sales growth strengthen in November after a weak outturn in October, the quarterly survey continues to paint a gloomy picture of the sector. Business sentiment remains poor, investment intentions are flat, and headcount continues to decline.”

Some analysts fear that Black Friday only served to pull forward sales which could have been booked at full price in October or December.

On Tuesday, fast fashion retailer Quiz reported a 2% fall in underlying profits in the six months to 30 September partly as a result of the £400,000 it was owed by House of Fraser when the department store fell into administration in August.

Offsetting the good period at John Lewis, the department store’s sister chain Waitrose had a difficult week. Sales slipped 1.6% despite a 43% rise in sales of mince pies and a 17% lift in mulled wine sales. Sales of homewares and other non-food were the hardest hit with sales down 6.9%.
